results.title: Walter and Milly went to read (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Tom Manefield, Film Australia and Karl McPhee
results.brief_description: Study of the reading abilities of children. Walter and Milly are ordinary children encountering the developmental tasks of their respective ages, with the usual successes and failures. Their parents and teachers try to create the best learning environment for the children. Photographer, John Hoskins; editor, Mark Waters; sound, Max Henser, Julian Ellingworth; music, Michael Carlos.

results.title: Walter
results.brief_description: This film acquaints the viewer with a young man - Walter - who has been a paraplegic since the age of three. He is a self-sufficient and cheerful person living alone but visiting his adoptive parent’s home daily for an evening meal. A determined student of architecture at the community college, Walter is also an active participant in the wheelchairs basketball team.

results.title: Walt Whitman's Leaves of grass
results.creator_credit: Line Films, Francis R. Line and Helen Line
results.brief_description: Uses the words of Walt Whitman, taken from his prose writings, diaries, note books and marginal manuscript notes, in presenting events in his life and in describing the influences which compelled him to write “Leaves of Grass”, his sympathetic observations of nature on Long Island and the people with whom he identified. Includes images of Long Island and New York in the 1960’s. Voice of Walt Whitman by Marvin Miller.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Line Films, Francis R. Line and Helen Line

results.title: Walt Whitman's Civil War
results.creator_credit: Churchill Films, Magus Films and Frederic Goodich
results.brief_description: Walt Whitman (played by Will Geer) moves through now-deserted fields remembering the “long solemn trenches”, the wounded, the dead, the thousands of personal tragedies of “The War of Attempted Secession”. Poems such as “Ashes of Soldiers” and “The Artilleryman’s Vision” are interspersed with his eye witness prose accounts of the war from the sound track and present the majesty and power of Whitman’s style. Archive photographs and filmed representations of the war are also featured.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Churchill Films, Magus Films and Frederic Goodich

results.title: Walt Disney Movie Viewer Cartridge [Snow White]
results.brief_description:
Walt Disney Movie Viewer
The first Movie Viewer was made in the USA in 1973 by Fisher Price. The British version was made by the Mettoy company. The viewer used Super 8 film and the actual clips were short pieces from real cartoon films. No technology was required to operate the viewer, not even batteries. The hand crank enabled the operator to view the film at any speed with the ability to go forwards or backwards at will.
